fields.title: FS In The News
Follow The Money

fields.description: Nem ezzel a címmel rendezett szakmai beszélgetést az ORTT Alkalmazott Kommunikációtudományi Intézete, de az eszmecsere végkicsengése szerint a magyar médiumok a tényfeltárás legfőbb akadályának annak magas költségét tekintik. A meghívott német-dán újságíró-szakértő szerint azonban ez a nehézség áthidalható.
fields.title: Népszabadság Online - A tényfeltáró újságírás luxus

fields.description: On connaît enfin la liste nominative des bénéficiaires des principales subventions agricoles de la PAC. Mediapart publie celle des 730 plus importants en France, extraite des données du ministère de l'agriculture par l'ONG farmsubsidy.org. Mais il y a encore beaucoup à faire pour que le citoyen (et contribuable) européen puisse comprendre le pourquoi de ces largesses. Petite plongée dans ces chiffres de la honte.
fields.title: Subventions agricoles en France: le système post-colonial se sucre | Mediapart

fields.description:
The people who brought European Union farm subsidy payments into the open (and who are behind the FollowTheMoney.eu website) are proud to announce the first European Open Data Summit, 5-7 May, in Brussels.
The Summit will bring together the farmsubsidy.org team and leading lights in access to information, investigative and computer-assisted reporting and ‘civic hacking’ for [...]
fields.title: First European Open Data Summit: 5-7 May, Brussels
fields.tags: Events, Featured, Latest, Legal, Take action, Brussels, data, EU, journalism, transparency

fields.description: ‘Access to EU documents’ is people’s fundamental right. A new European Parliament proposal marks a step in the right direction.  The up-coming Swedish EU-Presidency is a window of opportunity for transparency. We have to put in a lot of effort in the second half of 2009 in order to secure maximum access to EU documents.
fields.title: Give us maximum access to EU documents!
fields.tags: Featured, Latest, Legal, Take action, access to documents, corruption, right to access information, transparency, Transparency International

fields.description: Unfortunately, I have only come across this excellent document now. It seems like the German Federal Court of Auditors (”Bundesrechnungshof”) has understood the centrality of checking up on EU funds spent in Germany. As always under the motto “better late than never” - and in German style of comprehensiveness - a 200-page document has been [...]
fields.title: German court of auditors on EU funds in Germany
fields.tags: Analysis, Latest, New data, Bundesrechnungshof, CAP, EU report, Germany, Landesrechnungshof

fields.description: It’s one thing to complain that the rules defining responsibilities for managing the EU budget are inappropriate for the current structure and policies of the EU. It’s another thing to propose a way forward, a way towards more transparency and accountability. There is certainly a lot of truth to the accusation, especially when it comes [...]
fields.title: Change Europe by reforming the budget
fields.tags: Featured, Latest, Legal, accountability, corruption, sanctions, shared management, Transparency International, treaty change

fields.description: Why does giving the public information about who gets a piece of the EU funds pie matter? Or does it matter at all? What if most of the EU’s citizens wouldn’t bother to check how tax money is spent? Well, any functioning democracy needs to have a meaningful debate about what happens with the budget. [...]
fields.title: New EU fund disclosure system a step forward, but not yet enough!
fields.tags: Latest, Legal, New data, disclosure system, EU budget, shared management, Transparency International

fields.description: There has been calm about the issue for quite a while and already in autumn 2008 the Commission did not have a firm view for when to come out with the Review. But now it is confirmed that the Commission’s Budget Review communication will not be published until late October 2009 when the new (Barroso) [...]
fields.title: Budget Review delayed until October
fields.tags: Analysis, Latest, Budget Review, DG Budget, EU budget

fields.description: Effective citizen budget monitoring requires data - and lots of it - but just as important the data needs to be accessible and comprehensible. Thanks to the European Transparency Initiative driven forward by Commission Vice-President Siim Kallas, the EU has come a long way in a short time on accepting the principles of budget transparency, [...]
fields.title: Budget monitoring and data standards
fields.tags: Featured, Ideas and inspiration, Latest, Take action, data, design, european transparency initiative, farmsubsidy.org, information architecture, mySociety, richard allan, Siim Kallas, standards, web

fields.description: The German federal government has long resisted publication of recipients of Common Agricultural Policy payments but finally, thanks to the transparency provisions of the EU Financial Regulation, it was required to release data at the end of last year on the recipients of EU rural development funds that total 678 million euros to 172 319 [...]
fields.title: Bavaria takes lion’s share of rural development funds
fields.tags: Analysis, Featured, Latest, New data, bavaria, bayern, CAP, farm, farm subsidies, rural development

fields.description: This week the Open Budget Initiative has released  its 2008 Open Budget Index which scores 85 countries based on the information madea available to the public throughout the budget process. The EU countries in the survey do well, with France and the UK among the top table of just five countries that provide ‘extensive’ [...]
fields.title: Open Budget Index shows EU countries leading the way
fields.tags: Analysis, Featured, Ideas and inspiration, accountability, africa, aid, civil society, corruption, index, international budget partnership, ngo, open budgets, resource curse, transparency

fields.description:
After a number of direction changes which I foresee for the first half of 2009 (see my article about them), the second half of 2009, beginning with the EU elections, will probably see a focus on personalities and institutional implications.
June will finally see the election of the new Parliament and obviously change should be expected. [...]
fields.title: 2009 and the EU budget - personalities and institutional politics
fields.tags: Analysis, Latest, 2009, budget, Böge, COBU, COCOBU, Commission, elections, EP, EU, European Parliament, Grybauskaite, Guy-Quint, Kallas, Lewandowski, Lisbon Treaty

fields.description: THE NAME and home town of every farmer in the country who received payments under the Common Agricultural Policy (Cap) in 2008 were published on the internet last night. Some 550 farmers and companies received more than €100,000 each in payments.
fields.title: Over €2bn paid to farmers and companies under EU Cap scheme - The Irish Times - Fri, May 01, 2009

fields.description: Zwei italienische Zuckerproduzenten stehen laut einer Nichtregierungsorganisation an der Spitze der Empfänger von EU-Agrarsubventionen. Die Gruppe Italia Zuccheri erhielt im vergangenen Jahr 140 Millionen Euro aus Brüssel, Konkurrent Eridania Sadam gut 125 Millionen Euro, wie aus einer am Donnerstag veröffentlichten Aufstellung der britischen Organisation Farmsubsidy.org hervorgeht.
fields.title: Wirtschaft: Bürger zahlt für Agrarkonzerne - Badische-Zeitung.de

fields.description: The farm subsidy figures published yesterday show for the first time exactly how much taxpayers' money rich landowners and members of the royal family are receiving from the public purse.
fields.title: Rich land owners scoop up crock of gold from EU | The Guardian

fields.description: European Union governments agreed Thursday to overhaul the way the trade bloc distributes tens of billions of euros in subsidies to farmers. But some critics said the measures did not go far enough and risked skewing markets further.
fields.title: European Farm Subsidies Are to Be Overhauled - International Herald Tribune

fields.description: With riches derived from land and investments, race horses and jewelry, Queen Elizabeth II may be one of Britain's wealthiest women, but a question has arisen: does she, or her son Prince Charles, supplement the royal income with farm subsidies from the European Union?
fields.title: Questions About Royal Land Test New British Disclosure Law | The New York Times

fields.description: The European Union can't always see where its own money goes after it has been doled out to member nations. But a look into British dairy subsidies shows the need for more transparency. Even Queen Elizabeth gets help from Europe.
fields.title: Cash Cows: EU Subsidies Fatten the Rich - SPIEGEL ONLINE

fields.description: Four Danish cabinet ministers, several of its MPs and even the country's EU commissioner receive payments under the Common Agricultural Policy running into millions of pounds.
fields.title: Danish MPs get millions in farm subsidy | The Observer

fields.description: Altro che aiuti ai lavoratori della terra. A ricevere milioni dalla Ue sono soprattutto multinazionali e latifondisti. Come il principe Carlo.
fields.title: Fondi per nobili e ai contadini solo le briciole | Panorama

fields.description: A campaign to force European countries to divulge how they divide up billions of euros in farm subsidies has spread from Britain and Denmark to engulf the Netherlands, with the Dutch agriculture minister being forced to disclose publicly his personal farming interests.
fields.title: Dutch minister got farm subsidy | International Herald Tribune

fields.description: Le commissaire européen en charge de la lutte anti-fraude l'Estonien Siim Kallas souhaite "voir la France publier" publier pour "tous les citoyens" la liste des bénéficiaires des fonds européens de la Politique agricole commune (PAC), dans un entretien à La Tribune à paraître jeudi.
fields.title: Agrisalon.com - UE: la France devrait publier la liste des bénéficiaires de la PAC (Kallas)

fields.description: Al titolare del Dicastero dell'Agricoltura 190 mila euro dal bilancio Ue. L'interessato si oppone a eventuali tagli di aiuti comunitari
fields.title: Sussidi Ue alla fattoria del ministro olandese | Corriere della Sera

fields.description: Deutschland gibt weiter als einziges Land keine Auskunft. Zwei italienische Zuckerproduzenten stehen laut einer Nichtregierungsorganisation an der Spitze der Empfänger von EU-Agrarsubventionen.
fields.title: Italienische Zuckerproduzenten erhalten meiste EU-Agrarsubventionen | Mittelbayerische Zeitung

fields.description:
EU funds for rural areas through the LEADER programme appear to be a self-service buffet for local actors, without proper evaluation, new Danish research has revealed.

The programme is financed by EU structural funds with the aim of encouraging and helping rural actors to think about the longer-term potential of their area.
fields.title: EUobserver / EU rural aid scheme serves own masters

fields.description: II. Erzsébet angol királynő, Albert monacói herceg, az unió agrárbiztosa, a holland és a szlovák szakminiszter, a Philip Morris és a Nestlé - ők is a közös mezőgazdasági politika nagy haszonélvezői. Az EU-költségvetési viták közepette különösen kínos felfedezés ez.
fields.title: Üveggé varázsolják az EU zsebeit | Népszabadság Online

fields.description:
A Europe-wide network of investigative journalists will today (1 December) launch a website with detailed information about the end-recipients of EU farm support.

Last year, the European Union spent €43.5 billion on agriculture, more than 40 percent of the whole EU budget. But in most countries information on who gets the money is kept secret.
fields.title: New website exposes recipients of EU farm support | EUobserver

fields.description: This may seem like a daft question to ask on a budget monitoring website, but a look at farmsubsidy.org’s list of agri-millionaires will show that it is somewhat vexing. Near the top of the list is the Instituto Centrale Delle Banche Popolari Italiane, an Italian banking group, which according to the figures produced by the [...]
fields.title: What is a beneficiary of EU funds?
fields.tags: Analysis, Featured, Latest, Legal, beneficiary, CAP, credit agricole, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org, Instituto Centrale Delle Banche Popolari Italiane, law, transparency

fields.description: Thanks to everyone who came to the press conference / briefing session at the International Press Centre in Brussels this afternoon. It was a short but intense session in front of a packed audience and a great way to seal three intensive days of the first European Open Data Summit. There were some great contributions [...]
fields.title: Analysis presented at today’s press conference in Brussels
fields.tags: Analysis, Events, New data, Brussels, CAP, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org

fields.description:
This is a first of a few articles from the European Open Data Summit taking place in Brussels this week. I shall publish some thoughts, reports and news on this blog but there might also be articles on farmsubsidy.org. You can follow participants through the Twitter tag #eods09.
The event will close with a press conference [...]
fields.title: What is happening at the European Open Data summit?
fields.tags: Events, Latest, #eods09, 2009, Brussels, EODS, European Open Data Summit, International Press Centre, Residence Palace

fields.title: Transparency at last - but now we need YOUR help!
fields.tags: New data, Take action, CAP, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org, transparency

fields.description: The European Commission’s own Financial Transparency System, which publishes data on end beneficiaries of a range of grants and contracts, was launched at the end of 2008, but with a fatal flaw, common to many government data websites. The website only offered a web-form based interface and there was no way to access the entire [...]
fields.title: How to spend €10 billion
fields.tags: Analysis, Latest, New data, Afghanistan, data, European Commission, financial transparency system, foreign aid, foreign policy, Romania, Siim Kallas

fields.description: Along with the current regulations of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) certain transparency requirements have been introduced as part of the new EU financial regulation. However, German agriculture minister Ilse Aigner (CSU, pictured below) yesterday recommended to the responsible Länder ministries NOT to follow these rules and keep the list of beneficiaries secret because of [...]
fields.title: Incredible refusal of German ministry to publish CAP recipients
fields.tags: Analysis, Latest, Aigner, CAP, CSU, Germany, Seehofer, Sonnleitner

fields.description:
Ab dem 30. April – so die Entscheidung der EU und ihrer Mitgliedsländer – soll offengelegt werden, wer die gut 50 Milliarden jährlicher Euro an Agrarsubventionen bekommt. Aber jetzt will die neue Ministerin in Berlin die Durchführung der gemeinsamen Entscheidung eigentlich, vielleicht, wenn sie sich’s recht überlegt lieber doch nicht.
Seit Jahrzehnten fliessen Milliarden öffentlicher Gelder [...]
fields.title: EU-Recht? Ist Berlin doch egal!
fields.tags: Analysis, Aigner, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org, Germany

fields.description:
PRESS RELEASE: IMMEDIATE 
 
Just days before the 30 April deadline for disclosure of recipients of EU farm subsidies, the German farms minister Ilse Aigner has requested that the principle of budget transparency be suspended.  
 
Jack Thurston, co-founder of farmsubsidy.org, said: 
"This is a disgrace. The handful of politicians and judges in Germany who are [...]
fields.title: Press Release: German backsliding on farm subsidy transparency is a disgrace

fields.description: The people who brought European Union farm subsidy payments into the open (and who are behind the FollowTheMoney.eu website) are proud to announce the first European Open Data Summit, 5-7 May, in Brussels. The Summit will bring together the farmsubsidy.org team and leading lights in access to information, investigative and computer-assisted reporting and ‘civic hacking’ [...]
fields.title: First European Open Data Summit: 5-7 May, Brussels

fields.description: The Commission will adopt the 2010 Preliminary Draft Budget (PDB) next Wednesday, 29 April 2009. Commissioner Kallas (pictured below) take the place of Commissioner Grybauskaite who is campaigning in Lithuania and present the figures to Members of the EP Budget Committee (COBU) either in a special meeting directly afterwards or at an alternative meeting on [...]
fields.title: Commission to present Preliminary Draft Budget (PDB)
fields.tags: Events, Latest, Barroso, budget 2010, campaign, greenwashing, Grybauskaite, PDB 2010, Siim Kallas

fields.description: NEXT week sees both a European Union summit in Brussels devoted to the EU budget and a Hong Kong ministerial conference to review the Doha round of world trade talks. At first sight the two meetings might seem unconnected. But they share a crucial common thread: the attachment of the rich West, especially Europe, to farm subsidies. Indeed, the EU's common agricultural policy (CAP) will lie at the root of many of the arguments in both Hong Kong and Brussels.
fields.title: The follies of the EU agricultural policy | Economist.com

fields.description: The largest individual payments made to the UK under the much criticised common agricultural policy are going to multinational food companies and not, as commonly assumed, to farmers.
fields.title: Multinationals, not farmers, reap biggest rewards in Britain's share of CAP payouts | The Guardian
fields.tags: fsinthenews, uk, pub20051208, agriculture, food, farming

fields.description:
A Labour Euro-MP has criticised the Assembly Government for keeping secret the identities of those receiving a total of £230m in farm subsidy payments.

While England, Scotland and Northern Ireland all name the recipients of such subsidies, that is not the case in Wales.
fields.title: Euro-MP criticises silence on who in Wales gets farm cash | WalesOnline

fields.description: Wer profitiert von den milliardenschweren EU-Agrarsubventionen? Die deutschen Behörden halten es bis heute geheim. Aber der Druck wächst, die Zahlen zu veröffentlichen.
fields.title: Agrarsubventionen : Die dickste Kohle für die reichsten Bauern - STERN.DE

fields.description: Die EU schien - selbstlos - zu größten Zugeständnissen bereit zu sein. Bei den Verhandlungen der Welthandelsorganisation (WTO) Ende vergangenen Jahres in Hongkong erklärte der Staatenbund: Um durchschnittlich 47 Prozent wolle er seine Zölle auf landwirtschaftliche Produkte senken.
fields.title: Europas Bauern haben ihre Ruhe | die Tageszeitung

fields.description: Die größten Profiteure von EU-Agrarsubventionen in Deutschland sind Lebensmittelunternehmen und Eigentümer von Großgütern, nicht etwa kleinere Agrarbetriebe. Wie aus einem internen Papier der Bundesregierung hervorgeht, haben allein die 30 größten Empfänger von Exportsubventionen im Jahr 2001 umgerechnet 113 Millionen Euro aus dem europäischen Agrarhaushalt erhalten.
fields.title: Agrarsubventionen in Europa: Brüssel unterstützt selbst Nestlé und die Queen - FAZ.NET

fields.description: All member states should fully disclose who gets what from the EU budget and all Brussels lobbyists should sign up to a voluntary register and code of conduct, the European Commission proposed in a new discussion paper on Wednesday (3 May).
fields.title: Commission launches face-saving transparency drive | EUobserver

fields.description: A proposal to disclose the identity of those at the receiving end of EU funds - mainly farmers and fishermen - could face opposition from member states such as France which currently claim privacy over agriculture payments.
fields.title: EU transparency to cover CAP pay-outs? | EurActiv.com

fields.description:
Just 20% of Welsh farmers received 60% of the £223m in EU farm subsidies paid out in Wales within the past year, it can be revealed today.

And the top 10% took 40% of the millions.
fields.title: WalesOnline - News - Politics - Politics News - Small farms losing out to EU's big estates

fields.description: Europe's top dairy firms are at the centre of the row over European Union export subsidies, after a new report revealed which UK dairies are lapping up the aid.
fields.title: Top dairy firms guzzling EU subsidies | DairyReporter.com

fields.description: British-based exporters, including Nestle and Dairy Crest, have claimed £126m of taxpayers' money over the past two years for sending surplus butter and milk powder to poor countries such as Nigeria and Bangladesh, according to a new report obtained exclusively by The Observer.
fields.title: Who's creaming off EU subsidies? | The Observer

fields.description: Export subsidies for dairy products have come under fire in a new report from pressure group Farmsubsidy.org. Author Jack Thurston said the dumping of cheap commodity products in developing countries was harming local dairy producers by making it harder for them to develop sustainable businesses.
fields.title: Dairy UK slams call to axe export refunds - 24/05/2006 - FarmersWeekly

fields.description: Danske fødevarevirksomheder fik mere end 3,8 mia. kr. i lommen fra EUs bugnende kasse i 2005. Arla og Danisco modtog hver over en milliard kroner, viser ny undersøgelse. Politisk tilfredshed med nedtrapning af landbrugsstøtten.
fields.title: Milliardstøtte fra EU til Arla og Danisco - Nyhedsoversigt

fields.description: Fem danske storgodser fik allermest i EU-støtte i 2005. Bregentved, ejet af Chr. G. P. Moltke, var topscorer med 7,3 millioner kr. i EU-støtte i 2005, mens Frijsenborg og Wedellsborg, der begge er ejet af Bendt Wedell, fik 6,9 millioner kr.
fields.title: Store godser lever fedt på EU-støtten - Nyhedsoversigt

fields.description: International food giants Arla Foods and Danisco got more subsidies from the EU than anyone else in their native Denmark last year, says a new report, adding yet more controversy to Europe's farm support scheme.
fields.title: Arla, Danisco swallow Denmark's EU subsidies | DairyReporter.com

fields.description: Money, as in who gets what and what they do with it, seems to be an increasingly common theme in the media and on politicians’ lips.
fields.title: Following the money trail is never easy | Irish Examiner

fields.description: Britain’s biggest landowners, including some of the wealthiest aristocrats, would lose hundreds of millions of pounds in farm subsidies under plans being drawn up in Brussels. Mariann Fischer Boel, EU farm commissioner, will revive plans next year to put a ceiling on the subsidies any single landowner can receive, likely to be set at about €300,000 ($388,000, £206,000) a year.
fields.title: Big landowners to lose millions in EU reform | Financial Times

fields.description: The push for disclosure of information on agricultural payments to European farmers could highlight the need to introduce caps on subsidies, thinks commissioner Fischer Boel.
fields.title: EU agriculture commissioner ponders capping the CAP | EurActiv.com

fields.description: La commissaire européenne à l'Agriculture Mariann Fischer Boel s'est interrogée lundi sur la nécessité de plafonner les subventions aux agriculteurs européens, critiquées pour leur concentration en faveur des grandes exploitations et leur manque de transparence.
fields.title: La Commission s'interroge sur un plafonnement des aides | Terre-Net actualité

fields.description: Viele deutsche Politiker weigern sich, alle Empfänger von EU-Subventionen öffentlich zu machen. Als Bundestagsabgeordneter hatte Michael Glos oft den richtigen Instinkt. Da monierte der CSU-Politiker beispielsweise, dass »wichtige Fragen auf europäischer Ebene über die Köpfe der Menschen hinweg entschieden werden«. Mutig forderte er die »ehrliche Bestandsaufnahme«. Und mehr Transparenz sowieso.
fields.title: EU-Subventionen: Der Bürger soll dumm bleiben | ZEIT ONLINE

fields.description: Einen besseren Vorstoß hat die Europäische Kommission lange nicht gemacht. Wer die Europäer überzeugen wolle, daß die EU ihre Steuern sinnvoll ausgebe, müsse ihnen auch sagen, wohin das Geld fließe, fordert Kommissarin Mariann Fischer Boel. Sonst erwecke die EU nur den Eindruck, sie habe etwas zu verbergen. Von 2007 an sollen die Staaten deshalb nach Vorstellung der EU-Kommission jedes Jahr die Empfänger der Subventionen aus Brüssel veröffentlichen, etwa im Internet.
fields.title: Leitartikel Wirtschaft: Ans Tageslicht - Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung

fields.description: Die Summen sind groß, der Einblick ist gering: Die Bundesbürger zahlen pro Jahr etwa 9,3 Milliarden Euro der gigantischen EU-Subventionen für die Agrarindustrie - das ist rund ein Fünftel des Gesamttopfes. 6 Milliarden Euro überweist Brüssel wieder nach Berlin zurück. Nur: Wer wie viel davon abbekommt, wird verschwiegen. Damit kein Geld versickert, soll sich das ändern, fordert die EU-Kommission.
fields.title: Bekommen die Reichen am meisten? | taz.de

fields.description: Jeder Bundesbürger zahlt im Jahr durchschnittlich 250 Euro über Steuern in die EU-Kassen. 100 Euro davon gehen in die Landwirtschaft. Doch da endet schon die Transparenz. Was mit dem Geld passiert, wohin es fließt, wie es eingesetzt wird - darüber hat niemand einen vollständigen Überblick.
fields.title: Geheime Geldbewegung | taz.de

fields.description: The man who claims to be responsible for forcing the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) to publish farm subsidy details has accused the agency of making ‘glaring errors’ in this year’s figures.
fields.title: Glaring errors charge in aid figures | Farmers Guardian

fields.description: Europe's farmers received a record €48.5bn (£33bn) in subsidies from the controversial Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) in 2005, a jump of more than 11 per cent on a year earlier.
fields.title: Huge rise in subsidies for Europe's farmers | The Observer

fields.description: La France figure parmi les plus mauvais élèves pour la transparence sur la distribution de ces fonds, selon le réseau d'ONG farmsubsidy.org qui a publié mardi à Bruxelles un premier classement. C'est la Suède, avec un score de 95%, qui a accepté de fournir les données les plus complètes sur les bénéficiaires des subsides agricoles. Sur le podium, figurent également le Danemark (91%) et la Slovénie (87%). Avec 4%, la France est treizième et dernière des pays ayant accepté de donner quelques infos.
fields.title: La France épinglée sur les bénéficiaires des subventions agricoles | L'Expansion

fields.description: Over the next two years a ground-breaking decision by the council of ministers and the European Parliament will result in the biggest release of information held by governments to the public and the media since the creation of the European Union.
fields.title: Media law: So that's where the € 100 billion went | The Guardian
fields.tags: fsinthenews, uk, politics, cap, media, transparency, pub20070122, subsidies, gb

fields.description: Two years on and the Freedom of Information Act has been enough of a success to warrant its possible demise. While it was always naive to think that politicians would welcome open government, recent proposals have surprised even sceptics. Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, has described the Government as “taking a scythe to its own Act”.
fields.title: Freedom - only if we can get the information - Times Online

fields.description: The secrecy surrounding the biggest gravy train in the European Union - the €100bn in subsidies given each year to farms, fisheries, food companies and big infrastructure schemes across 27 countries - will be abolished over the next two years.
fields.title: Press forces EU subsidies issue | MediaGuardian

fields.description: Sveriges publicering av mottagare av jordbruksstöd får kritik. Jordbruksverkets hemsida gör det för svårt att analysera uppgifterna.
fields.title: Lista över stödmottagare kritiseras | ATL Nyheter

fields.description: Europe's costly system of farm subsidies is becoming increasingly skewed towards giant agri-businesses. Ninety firms in the UK are each banking more than €500,000 (£340,000) in taxpayers' cash in a single year, new figures from Brussels reveal.
fields.title: Farming giants reap most of EU's benefits | The Observer

fields.description: A hatalmas földbirtokokkal rendelkezők - így a brit királyi család -, a cukortermelők és a nagy cégek zsebelhették be tavaly is a legtöbb pénzt az Európai Unió agrártámogatásaiból. A magyar pénzek útját átláthatatlannak tartják egyes uniós szakértők.
fields.title: Birtokos esetek | Heti Válasz

fields.description: Im Netz kann sich jetzt jeder über die Empfänger von EU-Direktzahlungen informieren. Doch viele Länder verstecken die Zahlen, Deutschland weigert sich ganz.
fields.title: EU-Agrarsubventionen öffentlich: Die reichsten Bauern Europas | taz.de

fields.description: Η Γαλλία μπορεί να είναι η χώρα που εισπράττει τις περισσότερες κοινοτικές αγροτικές επιδοτήσεις της Κοινής Αγροτικής Πολιτικής (ΚΑΠ), όμως επιδοτήσεις αξίας πολλών εκατομμυρίων ευρώ έχουν ως αποδέκτες επιχειρήσεις κυρίως της Ιταλίας και της Ισπανίας, σύμφωνα με έρευνα που πραγματοποίησε ο όμιλος Farmsubsidy. Το συμπέρασμα της έρευνας είναι πως το 5 -10% της ΚΑΠ απορροφούν 707 μεγάλες αγροτικές επιχειρήσεις. Το αξιοπερίεργο είναι ότι η Ελλάδα απουσιάζει πλήρως από τους πίνακες, κάτι που σημαίνει ότι δεν υπάρχουν τέτοιου μεγέθους επιχειρήσεις στη χώρα μας.
fields.title: Η Ελλάδα απουσιάζει από τη λίστα «εκατομμυριούχων» των αγροτικών επιδοτήσεων της Ε.Ε.

fields.description: Правителствата на страните членки на ЕС представиха на ЕК непълна информация за бенефециентите на европейските агросубсидии. Това е в пряко нарушение на принципите на ЕС за прозрачност и добро управление, твърдят неправителствени организации, цитирани от Евроактив. Според представители на уеб страницата farmsubsidy.org повечето данни за получилите средства по програмите на Европейската селскостопанска политика са ''неизползваеми и не отговарят на европейските изисквания и регулации''.
fields.title: Новини - НПО алармираха за нарушения с агросубсидиите в ЕС | Dnevnik.bg

fields.description: European farmers used to fight globalization. Now, they are embracing it—and getting richer as a result.
fields.title: Europe’s New Herd Mentality | Newsweek

fields.description:
Alone among Europe’s 27 member states, Germany had been holding out against publishing data on farm subsidy recipient but today it has finally taken steps towards complying with the new EU law on budget transparency, some six weeks after the 30 April deadline. 
With elections now out of the way, the German federal government has [...]
fields.title: New data: 194 German farm subsidy millionaires
fields.tags: Latest, New data, bavaria, data, doux, farmsubsidy.org, Germany

fields.description: We are making good progress extracting all the farm subsidy payment data published on the German government’s website. While doing so we have found 21 recipients for whom no information on name, municipality or postcode is given. The total payments to these 21 recipients is 16.8 million euros, of which 8.9 million euros is in [...]
fields.title: Who are Germany’s ‘invisible men’?
fields.tags: Featured, Latest, New data, farmsubsidy.org, Germany, secrecy

fields.description: Arids Roma is a gritty Catalan construction company in the northeast of Spain that paves highways and churns out dusty gray mountains of gravel from several sprawling factories. It is also a beneficiary of €1.59 million in farm subsidies from the European Union, which last year doled out more than €50 billion, $71 billion, from the largest agricultural aid program in the world, one that provides financing to a wide variety of recipients beyond the farmers who plow the soil — German gummy bear manufacturers, luxury cruise ship caterers and wealthy landowners ranging from Queen Elizabeth II of England to Prince Albert II of Monaco.
fields.title: European Subsidies Stray From the Farm | New York Times / International Herald Tribune
fields.tags: fsinthenews, pub20090717, gb, ro, de, it, fr, es

fields.description: Új modellt kell kialakítani az újságírók munkájának finanszírozására. Az internet térnyerésének és a világgazdasági válság következtében már nem működnek az eddigi struktúrák - mondta lapunknak Brigitte Alfter díjnyertes dán-német oknyomozó újságíró.
fields.title: Őrülteknek való az oknyomozás | Népszabadság

fields.description: Nils Mulvad has completed the extraction of data from the German government’s website. It’s available to anyone to download as a raw zipped data file here. There are 247,356 payments totalling 5,230,144,601 euros. It is important to note that Bavaria continues to refuse to release its data, and we believe thta the payments in Germany’s [...]
fields.title: Germany’s farm subsidy data finally out
fields.tags: Analysis, Featured, Latest, New data, Aigner, farmsubsidy.org, Germany

fields.description: Thanks to everyone who came to the press conference / briefing session at the International Press Centre in Brussels this afternoon. It was a short but intense session in front of a packed audience and a great way to seal three intensive days of the first European Open Data Summit. There were some great contributions [...]

fields.description:
Ab dem 30. April – so die Entscheidung der EU und ihrer Mitgliedsländer – soll offengelegt werden, wer die gut 50 Milliarden jährlicher Euro an Agrarsubventionen bekommt. Aber jetzt will die neue Ministerin in Berlin die Durchführung der gemeinsamen Entscheidung eigentlich, vielleicht, wenn sie sich’s recht überlegt lieber doch nicht.
Seit Jahrzehnten fliessen Milliarden öffentlicher Gelder [...]
fields.title: EU-Recht? Ist Berlin doch egal!
fields.tags: Analysis, Aigner, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org, Germany

fields.description: Spain is the second biggest recipient of EU farm subsidies after France yet the question of who gets what is rarely discussed. Farmsubsidy.org has spent the past six months investigating by obtaining, compiling cleaning and analysing an enormous quantity of data on end beneficiaries of farm subsidies in Spain. It is a work in progress [...]
fields.title: Uncovering farm subsidies in Spain: a new dossier published

fields.title: Lots of new farm subsidy data now online
fields.tags: New data, data, farm subsidies, farmsubsidy.org

fields.description: EU agriculture subsidies worth billions of pounds under the CAP are being paid out to businesses and multinational corporations with little connection to traditional farming.
fields.title: EU farm subsidies paid to big business | Daily Telegraph

fields.description: Three Eurosceptic Conservative MPs have claimed more than £500,000 in EU farm subsidies in the past two years.
fields.title: Tory Eurosceptics claim EU farm money | Channel 4 News

fields.description: Three Conservative Eurosceptic MPs have received £500,000 through controversial Brussels farm subsidies over the past two years.
fields.title: Three Eurosceptic Tory MPs claim more than £500,000 in Brussels' subsidies in two years | Daily Telegraph

fields.description: Analysis of data on EU farm subsidies in the UK reveal that three Eurosceptic Conservative MPs have claimed more than £500,000 in EU farm subsidies in the past two years. A great piece of work by long-time farmsubsidy.org network member Annamarie Cumiskey for More4 News, the offshoot of Channel 4 News. The story was also [...]

fields.description: The Eastern Sugar company used to produce more than 100,000 metric tons of beet sugar per year in the Czech Republic. In 2006, the company announced it was pulling out of Central Europe altogether, and closing its three Czech facilities.
fields.title: EU incentives encourage firm to leave ČR | The Prague Post

fields.description: Farmsubsidy ha publicado un estudio de investigación en el que acusa a España de su poca "transparencia" a la hora de dar datos sobre subsidios agrarios
fields.title: El Almería - Nueve empresas almerienses, en el top 40 de ayudas de la UE

fields.description: Producteurs de riz camarguais, gros céréaliers, mais aussi industriels du poulet comme Doux... Tous les bénéficiaires des aides agricoles européennes sont désormais connus. Cela faisait des années que des associations, les médias ou encore la Confédération paysanne, l'ancien syndicat de José Bové, le réclamaient, au nom de la transparence de l'utilisation des fonds publics ou d'une meilleure répartition des subventions. La France avait jusque-là traîné des pieds.
fields.title: La France lève le voile sur les bénéficiaires des subventions agricoles - Economie - Le Monde.fr

fields.description: La asociación 'farmsubsidy.org' ha calificado con un 33 sobre 100 la «transparencia» de España a la hora de difundir datos sobre sus beneficiarios de ayudas de la Política Agrícola Común (PAC).
fields.title: España suspende en «transparencia», en opinión de una oenegé - hoyAgro - 12 April 2009

fields.description:
EU farm payments in the UK show rich farmers and companies benefit most, writes Ronan McGreevy

FARMERS MAY not be happy with the decision to have the money they receive in EU payments put into the public domain, but other professions have had to come to terms with it as a matter of course.

fields.description: Stepping off his huge Renault tractor, Nicolas Galpin squinted in the August sun past his metal grain silos and towards the fields ploughed by his father and his father's father before him.
fields.title: French farmers survive but multinationals cash in on EU subsidies | Daily Telegraph

fields.description: The EU spends the bulk of its budget on the wrong things, notably agriculture, which also causes political strife, argues Jack Thurston.

fields.description: When making a request for detailed information on government budgets it’s common to encounter resistance from the government officials who handle the request. They question why the information should be made public, they fear the consequences of releasing the information, they worry about the additional work that such requests may cause. The degree of resistance [...]
